answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hello,
I did not find a specific document that helps to determine the order to review services that may be outsourced however the following documents should be useful in determining which services should or should not be outsourced and help in creating a set of priorities based on the associated benefits and risks. 
A Strategic Guide for Local Government On:  OUTSOURCING from the Center for Digital Government -focuses on IT outsourcing but also provides guidelines on how to select functions for outsourcing. 
http://www-935.ibm.com/services/th/igs/pdf/au-ois-wp-strategic-guide-for-local-government-on-outsourcing.pdf 
An Outsourcing study conducted by the South Florida Water Management District- explains the general practices of the District for outsourcing as well as the costs, benefits and risks considered prior to outsourcing specific projects. 
http://www.sfwmd.gov/portal/page/portal/xrepository/sfwmd_repository_pdf/outsource.pdf
Managing High Risk Outsourcing - provides a framework for assessing potential risk of outsourcing as well as techniques that may be used to manage the outsourced project. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/2444/Managing_HighRisk_Outsourcing
I hope this is helpful,
Pooja Varma
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
pvarma@icma.org

answers.author: Susan Mays
answers.text:
Pam,
A good place to start the conversation is around your community's mission. Ask yourself what business(es) you want to be in, and what services could potentially be delivered more efficiently and cost-effectively by someone else. 
As part of a routine continuous improvement process, we usually suggest folks look at the "low-hanging fruit" first. In this case that would mean mean departments where you're having difficulty meeting budget or complying with regulations, or departments where you experience higher turnover or surveys show lower citizen satisfaction. 
Given that in today's economy cities and counties have had to reduce staff in some departments, these would be another area to examine early on. For example, if development has halted in your community, you may have had to reduce your plan review staff. Will you be able to staff back up when the economy improves? Probably not right away so this would be a good time to look at electronic plan review to reduce the number of staff needed and/or outsourcing to a firm can staff up and down as the economy dictates.
Hope this helps!
Susan 
susan.mays@ch2m.com
